example: Though many initially tried to impugn Darwin's theory, in scientific circles today, the idea is taken as truth.

meaning: Free of guilt; not subject to blame; beyond doubt or reproach
example: After his long and unimpeachable service to the company, Sharat felt that a gold watch was a slap in the face rather than an honor.

meaning: Young and inexperienced
example: Both Los Angeles and New York are known for callow out-of-towners hoping to make it big.

meaning: Immune to attack; without flaws
example: Professor Williams is so self-assured as to seem arrogant, presenting each and every opinion as an unassailable fact.

meaning: (of conflict) within a group or organization
example: The guerilla group, which had become so powerful as to own the state police, was finally destroyed by an internecine conflict.

meaning: Associated with or participating in an activity, especially one of a questionable nature.
example: While the grand jury cleared the senator of all criminal charges, in the public mind he was still complicit in the corruption.

meaning: Convert (someone) to another religion, philosophy, or perspective
example: Lisa loves her Mac but says little about it; by contrast, Jake will proselytize, interrogating anyone with an Android about why she didn't purchase an iPhone.

meaning: Showing hovering attentiveness
example: Our neighbors are constantly knocking on our door to make sure we are ok, and I don't know how to ask them to stop being so solicitous about our health.

meaning: Brave; bold; courageous
example: I enjoy films in which a doughty group comes together to battle a force of evil.

meaning: (of e.g. speech and writing) tending to depart from the main point
example: Many readers find it tough to read Moby Dick since the author is discursive, often cutting the action short to spend 20 pages on the history of a whale.

meaning: The act of restraining power or action or limiting excess ; To react with anger or to take offense
example: New curfew laws have bridled people's tendency to go out at night. ; The hostess bridled at the tactless dinner guests who insisted on eating before everybody had gotten their food.

meaning: Injustice by virtue of not conforming with rules or standards
example: After decades of racial inequity, the "separate but equal" doctrine was successfully overturned.

meaning: Characteristic of an absolute ruler or absolute rule; having absolute sovereignty ; Offensively self-assured or given to exercising usually unwarranted power
example: The last true autocratic country is certainly North Korea; nowhere does a leader exercise the absolute control over all aspects of a people the way that Kim Jong-un does. ; The manager was finally fired for his autocratic leadership, which often bordered on rude and offensive.

meaning: Reluctant to draw attention to yourself
example: The most admirable teachers and respected leaders are those who are self-effacing, directing attention and praise to their students and workers.

meaning: Great coolness and composure under strain
example: Nancy acted with aplomb during dangerous situations--she once calmly climbed up an oak tree to save a cat.

meaning: Something desired as a necessity
example: The desideratum of the environmental group is that motorists should rely on carpooling.

meaning: Transparently clear; easily understandable
example: The professor had a remarkable ability to make even the most difficult concepts seem pellucid.

meaning: Mix together different elements or concepts
example: In her recent book, the author conflates several genres--the detective story, the teen thriller, and the vampire romance--to create a memorable read.

meaning: Highly or widely praised or boasted about
example: For years, they had heard of New York City's vaunted skyline, and when they finally saw it, the spectacular cityscape did not disappoint them in the least.

meaning: Having an extremely bad smell
example: Each August, when the winds moved in a south easterly direction, the garbage dump would spread noisome vapors through the small town.

meaning: A very intense and uncontrolled fire
example: In the summer months, conflagrations are not uncommon in the southwest, due to the heat and lack of rain.

meaning: A formal expression of praise
example: Dave asked Andrew to do just a simple toast, but Andrew launched into a full panegyric, enumerating a complete list of Dave's achievements and admirable qualities.

meaning: Formally reject or give up (as a belief)
example: While the church believed that Galileo abjured the heliocentric theory under threat of torture, he later wrote a book clearly supporting the theory.

meaning: Never to be broken, infringed, or dishonored
example: To many the grass at Wimbledon is inviolable and only greater tennis players are able to enjoy a game there.

meaning: Showing sorrow
example: Chopin's ballades are filled with sharp changes in moods--a dolorous melody can give way to a lighthearted tempo.

meaning: Command against
example: My doctor proscribed my habit of eating donuts with chocolate sauce and hamburger patties for breakfast.

meaning: Resourcefulness and determination
example: Wallace Stegner lamented the lack of gumption in the U.S. during the sixties, claiming that no young person knew the value of work.

meaning: Someone shirking their duty by pretending to be sick or incapacitated
example: At one time, our country was full of hardworking respectful people, but now it seems that everyone is a malingerer with little inclination to work.

meaning: Overbearing pride evidenced by a superior manner toward inferiors
example: As soon as she won the lottery, Alice began displaying a hauteur to her friends, calling them dirty-clothed peasants behind their backs.

meaning: Characterized by lightness and insubstantiality
example: Because she dances with an ethereal style, ballet critics have called her Madame Butterfly.

meaning: Provide with an opportunity
example: The summit of Mt. Kilimanjaro affords a panoramic view that encompasses both Tanzania and Kenya.

meaning: To give or take something by force ; To allocate
example: The government appropriated land that was occupied by squatters, sending them scurrying for another place to live. ; The committe appropriated the funds to its various members.

meaning: An act of extreme wickedness
example: The enormity of Pol Pot's regime is hard to capture in words--within months hundreds of thousands of Cambodians lost their lives.

meaning: Intellectually productive
example: The artist had entered a fecund period, producing three masterpieces in the span of two months.

meaning: Acceptable to the taste or mind
example: Mikey didn't partake much in his friends' conversations, but found their presence palatable.

meaning: Showing a cheerful willingness to do favors for others
example: On her first day at the job, Annie was complaisant, fulfilling every request of her new employer and anticipating future requests.

meaning: Someone new to a field or activity
example: All great writers, athletes, and artists were tyros at one time—unknown, clumsy, and unskilled with much to learn.

meaning: Not admitting of passage or capable of being affected
example: I am not impervious to your insults; they cause me great pain.

meaning: Change or alter in form, appearance, or nature
example: One of the goals of alchemy was to find the substance or process that would transmute lead into gold.

meaning: Talk in a dogmatic and pompous manner
example: The vice-president would often pontificate about economic theory, as if no one else in the room were qualified to speak on the topic.

meaning: (of language) pompous and tedious
example: The amount of GRE vocabulary he used increased with his years--by the time he was 60, his novels were so turgid that even his diehard fans refused to read them.

meaning: A pauper who lives by begging
example: Tolstoy was an aristocrat, but he strove to understand the Christianity of the Russian peasants by wandering among them as a mendicant.

meaning: Uninteresting, lacking vitality
example: Few novelists over 80 are able to produce anything more than desiccated works--boring shadows of former books.

meaning: Arrived at without due care or effort; lacking depth
example: Many news shows provide facile explanations to complex politics, so I prefer to read the in-depth reporting of The New York Times.

meaning: Slow to learn or understand; lacking intellectual acuity; lacking in insight or discernment
example: Jackson was the most obtuse member of the team: the manager's subtle ironies were always lost on him.

meaning: Being of equal extent or scope or duration
example: The border of the state is coterminous with geographic limits on travel; the east and north are surrounded by a nearly uncrossable river and the south by a desert.

meaning: With care and persistence
example: The top college football program recruits new talent assiduously, only choosing those who were the top in their county.

meaning: A trite or obvious remark
example: Instead of sharing his umbrella, the cheeky stranger offered Martha the following bromide: "Looks like it's raining."

meaning: Expressing sorrow
example: Few can listen to the elegiac opening bars of the Moonlight sonata without feeling the urge to cry.

meaning: Cause one, through routine, to lose energy and enthusiasm
example: As an undergraduate Mark felt stultified by classes outside his area of study; only in grad school, in which he could focus solely on literary analysis, did he regain his scholarly edge.

meaning: Impossible to avoid or evade
example: For those who smoke cigarettes for years, a major health crisis brought on by smoking is ineluctable.

meaning: Revoke or relinquish formally; do away with
example: As part of the agreement between the labor union and the company, the workers abrogated their right to strike for four years in exchange for better health insurance.

meaning: To surrender (usually under agreed conditions)
example: Paul, losing 19-0 in a ping-pong match against his nimble friend, basically capitulated when he played the last two points with his eyes closed.

meaning: Droop, sink, or settle from or as if from pressure or loss of tautness; become less intense
example: After the three crushing defeats in the last three games, the team's enthusiasm began to flag.

meaning: Truthfully, without a doubt
example: Frank is a veritable life-saver -- last year, on two different occasions, he revived people using CPR.

meaning: Inappropriate
example: During the executive meeting, the marketing director continued to make infelicitous comments about the CEO's gambling habit.

meaning: Be valid, applicable, or true
example: The custom of waiting your turn in line does not obtain in some countries, in which many people try to rush to front of the line at the same time.

meaning: State or announce
example: The President wanted to promulgate the success of the treaty negotiations, but he had to wait until Congress formally approved the agreement.

meaning: An act that debases or corrupts
example: The movie World War Z is a complete bastardization of the book with little more in common than zombies and a title.

meaning: To deceive or trick someone
example: Someone tried to hoodwink Marty with an email telling him that his uncle had just passed away, and to collect the inheritance he should send his credit card information.

meaning: An excessive amount of something
example: There was no such thing as a surfeit of shopping for Nancy--she could stay at the outlet stores from opening to closing time.

meaning: A contrary command cancelling or reversing a previous command
example: By the time the colonel countermanded his soldiers not to land in enemy territory, a few helicopters had already touched down amid heavy gunfire.

meaning: A deliberately misleading fabrication
example: The public will always be fooled by the media's canards.

meaning: Draw from specific cases for more general cases
example: By extrapolating from the data on the past three months, we can predict a 5% increase in traffic to our website.

meaning: Hypothetical remedy for all ills or diseases; a universal solution
example: While the company credit card has made most large purchases easier, it is no panacea: some smaller basic transactions still must be conducted in cash.

meaning: To erroneously attribute; to falsely ascribe; used especially of authorship.
example: I made a mistake; I misattributed "Crime and Punishment" to Leo Tolstoy when it was actually written by Fyodor Dostoyevsky.

meaning: Corruption, usually through bribery
example: In countries with rampant graft, getting a driver's license can require no more than paying an official.

meaning: Deserving of esteem and respect
example: After serving thirty years, in which he selflessly served the community, Judge Harper was one of the more estimable people in town.

meaning: Disdainfully or ironically humorous; scornful and mocking
example: A stand-up comedian walks a fine line when making jokes about members of the audience; such fun and joking can quickly become sardonic and cutting.

meaning: Characterized by or full of force and vigor; having keenness and forcefulness and penetration in thought, expression, or intellect
example: Jill presented a rather superficial treatment of sales in Asia, but her trenchant analysis of sales in Europe inspired a number of insights into how to proceed in that market.

meaning: Idyllically calm and peaceful; suggesting happy tranquillity; marked by peace and prosperity
example: The first decade after WWI was a halcyon period in America with new-found wealth and rapidly improving technology.

meaning: A representation of a person (especially in the form of sculpture) ; A bad imitation
example: The Shanghai Urban Planning Exhibition Center showcases a simulacrum of all the present and approved buildings in the city of Shanghai. ; The early days of computer graphics made real people into a simulacrum that now seems comical.

meaning: A living full of debauchery and indulgence in sensual pleasure
example: Many Roman emperors were known for their dissolution, indulging in unspeakable desires of the flesh.

meaning: An angry dispute
example: The Prime Minister looked very foolish after his row with the foreign dignitary was caught on video and posted on youtube.

meaning: Fanatical patriotism; belief that one's group/cause is superior to all other groups/causes
example: Vegetarians argue that man is chauvinistic in his belief that animals do not consciously feel the pain we humans do.

meaning: To serve as a judge in a competition; to arrive at a judgment or conclusion
example: Only those with the most refined palates were able to adjudicate during the barbeque competition.

meaning: Very irritable
example: Ever since the car accident, Frank has been unable to walk without a cane, and so he has become splenetic and unpleasant to be around.

meaning: Tending to vanish like vapor
example: The storm flashed into existence above us and lasted only a short time—an evanescent turbulence of wind and cloud.

meaning: The name derived from a person (real or imaginary); the person for whom something is named
example: Alexandria, Egypt is an eponym because it is named after Alexander the Great.

meaning: Strongly attracted to or in love with.
example: She is completely enamored with Justin Bieber, and goes to all his concerts on the East coast.

meaning: A cruel and oppressive dictator
example: The Emperor Claudius was regarded as a fair-minded leader; his successor, Nero, was an absolute despot.

meaning: Given to or marked by the open expression of emotion
example: When Sally told James that she wanted to break up with him, she expected he would react demonstratively, but he quietly nodded his head and left without saying a word.

meaning: Ridicule or expose to public scorn
example: After the candidate confessed, the press of the opposing party took the opportunity to pillory him, printing editorials with the most blatantly exaggerated accusations.

meaning: The appearance of truth
example: All bad novels are bad for numerous reasons; all good novels are good for their verisimilitude of reality, placing the readers in a world that resembles the one they know.

meaning: Greatly exceeding bounds of reason or moderation
example: Shelley made one exorbitant purchase after another, buying new clothes and taking vacations even though she earned a limited salary.

meaning: Conceal one's true motives, usually through deceit
example: To get close to the senator, the assassin dissembled his intentions, convincing many people that he was a reporter for a well-known newspaper.

meaning: Describing an event or situation that happens at the same time as or in connection with another
example: Concomitant with his desire for nature was a desire for the culture and energy of a big city.

meaning: A small or moderate or token amount
example: If my sister had even a modicum of sense, she wouldn't be engaged to that barbarian.

meaning: Unhappy in love; suffering from unrequited love ; Sorrowful through loss or deprivation
example: After 64 years of marriage, William was bereft after the death of his wife. ; "You are not bereft if you haven't played on your Xbox in the past week," his mother said.

meaning: Not straightforward; indirect
example: Herbert never explicitly revealed anything negative about Tom's past, but at times he would obliquely suggest that Tom was not as innocent as he seemed.

meaning: To indicate smallness ; Very small
example: He prefers to be called a diminutive of his name: "Bill" instead of "John William." ; When he put on his father's suit and shoes, his appearance was that of a diminutive youth.

meaning: Speak (about unimportant matters) rapidly and incessantly
example: During the rain delay, many who had come to see the game palavered, probably hoping that idle chatter would make the time go by faster.

meaning: Joyously unrestrained
example: Can you blame him for his ebullient mood? He just graduated from medical school.

meaning: An event resulting in great loss and misfortune
example: The introduction of smallpox was a cataclysm for Native Americans, killing off more than half of their population.

meaning: Unwilling to do something contrary to your custom (usually followed by 'to')
example: I was loath to leave the concert before my favorite band finished playing.

meaning: Light teasing
example: The new recruit was not bothered by the raillery, finding most of it light-hearted and good-natured.

meaning: The quality of being meager
example: After two months at sea, the exiguity of the ship's supplies forced them to search for fresh water and food.

meaning: Squander or spend money frivolously ; To disperse or scatter
example: The recent graduates dissipated their earnings on trips to Las Vegas and cruises in Mexico. ; Kathleen's perfume was overwhelming in the cramped apartment, but once we stepped outside the smell dissipated and we could breathe once again.

meaning: Showing sorrow
example: Lachrymose and depressed, Alexei Alexandrovich walked two miles home in the rain after learning that his wife was having an affair.

meaning: Intrusive in a meddling or offensive manner
example: The professor had trouble concentrating on her new theorem, because her officious secretary would barge in frequently reminding her of some trivial detail involving departmental paperwork.
